metadata.titleEn: Fungal spores data and A/C ratio data from Tian’E Lake over the past ~3500 years
metadata.description: Data description: The data sets contains the content of fungal spores and A/C ratio data from Tian’E Lake (39°14′20″N, 97°55′26″E, altitude 3012 m) in the western part of the Qilian Mountains at the northern margin of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau over the past ~3,500 years. We have completed the fungal spores and pollen analyses of 520 sedimentary samples. We use analyses of pollen A/C ratio and Sporormiella-type coprophilous fungal spores to reconstruct changes in regional moisture and grazing intensity over the past ~3,500 years in an arid mountain-basin system. Our results provide a historical reference for understanding how ancient people adapted to the climate change in arid region with high mountains. The data is stored in Excel format.
metadata.instructions: Fungal spores data and pollen ratio data from Tian’E Lake over the past ~3500 years

literatureList.titleEn: An inverse relationship between moisture and grazing intensity in an arid mountain-basin system
literatureList.referenceEn: Zhang, J., Huang, X.Z., Wang, J.L., Bradshaw, R.H.W., Wang, T., Xiang, L.X., Luo, D.R., Wang, Z.L., Chen, F.H. (2022). An inverse relationship between moisture and grazing intensity in an arid mountain-basin system. Progress in Physical Geography: Earth and Environment, 46(2), 310-322. https://doi.org/10.1177/03091333211060000

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of the data collection methods used for analyzing fungal spores and pollen A/C ratio in sedimentary samples from mountain-basin systems?
Feature Specification.Answer: Sporormiella-type coprophilous fungal spores, pollen A/C ratio

Quantification.Question: How many sedimentary samples have been analyzed to obtain fungal spores and A/C ratio data from Tian’E Lake over the past ~3500 years?

Definition.Question: What is the A/C ratio in the context of pollen analysis?
Definition.Answer: The A/C ratio in the context of pollen analysis refers to the ratio of arboreal (tree) pollen to non-arboreal (herbaceous) pollen. It is used to infer changes in vegetation types and, by extension, climatic conditions, particularly regional moisture levels, over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors could have influenced the methods used to collect fungal spores and A/C ratio data from sediment samples at Tian’E Lake over the past ~3500 years?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The methods for collecting fungal spores and A/C ratio data from Tian’E Lake over the past ~3500 years could have been influenced by the need to accurately reconstruct historical regional moisture and grazing intensity. This requires detailed pollen and fungal spore analyses from sedimentary samples to provide insights into how ancient people adapted to climatic changes. The geographical location and altitude of the lake, as well as the arid mountain-basin system in which it is situated, would also necessitate specific and careful data collection techniques to ensure the validity and reliability of the data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of utilizing pollen A/C ratio and Sporormiella-type coprophilous fungal spores to reconstruct historical climate and grazing intensity in arid mountain-basin systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing pollen A/C ratio and Sporormiella-type coprophilous fungal spores allows researchers to reconstruct changes in regional moisture and grazing intensity over the past ~3,500 years. This approach provides a historical reference for understanding how ancient people adapted to climate change in the arid region with high mountains, offering insights into past environmental conditions and human-environment interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind analyzing fungal spores and A/C ratio data to understand historical human adaptation to climate change in arid mountain-basin systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim is to reconstruct changes in regional moisture and grazing intensity over the past ~3,500 years, providing a historical reference for understanding how ancient people adapted to climate change in arid regions with high mountains.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in analyzing pollen A/C ratio and Sporormiella-type coprophilous fungal spores to reconstruct historical regional moisture and grazing intensity over the past ~3,500 years?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The analysis involves collecting sedimentary samples from Tian’E Lake, conducting pollen and fungal spore analyses on these samples, calculating the A/C ratio from pollen data, and interpreting the Sporormiella-type coprophilous fungal spores content. These analyses aim to deduce changes in regional moisture and grazing intensity, considering the historical context provided by the sedimentary record.
